oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Emancipation Day, Greenwood Park, Monday, Aug. 9, '09
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Civic Engagement
Slaves -- Emancipation -- United States -- Anniversaries, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for the Emancipation Day celebration to be held in Greenwood Park in Nashville.

Following the Civil War, Emancipation Day celebrations traditionally took place on August 8th in Tennessee. This ad published on July 23, 1909 in the Nashville Globe, an African American newspaper, gives the program for the August 9, 1909, celebration at Greenwood Park, an African American park in Nashville. The program was to include a military drill and dress parade commanded by Capt. Henry H. Bowman.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This image is in the public domain and may be used freely.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Warfield Masonic Lodge
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gardner, Leigh Ann, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
African American fraternal organizations
Fraternal lodges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-story brick, two-bay wide, commercial building. The building has wooden siding on street level and a projecting shed porch running the width of the building. Stone belt courses define the floor levels, and the building has two entrance doors, each of which has a three-paned window with arched lintel centered above it on the second level, and another centered above that window on the third level. Brickwork detailing includes six projecting bracket forms across the top of building.

The Warfield Lodge No. 44, F. & A.M. (P.H.A.) dates to the 1890s, when the Tennessee Grand Lodge issued the charter for the group. The lodge purchased a lot in Clarksville at the corner of Ninth and Main Streets in 1899, and by 1901 owned the property. The first lodge hall burned in 1911, and was rebuilt/remodeled in 1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Historic marker at the Zion Christian Cemetery.

The United Sons of Zion were one of the oldest African American fraternal groups in Memphis, Tennessee. In 1873, the group purchased 15 acres to establish a cemetery for its members. Burials began in 1876, and more than 30,000 African Americans are buried in the cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lincoln Rosenwald School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American schools; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: United States -- Tennessee -- Bledsoe County -- Pikeville
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Beginning in 1912, the Rosenwald Fund, started by Julius Rosenwald, helped construct thousands of schools for African Americans across the South. Built in 1925, the Lincoln School is an excellent example of the standardized architecture of the schools that were specified in the Community School Plans. The Rosenwald Fund provided $900 for the construction of the Lincoln School, the local African American community provided $1,200, and county and state government provided $3236 for its construction.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders portrait of a young man in collarless shirt and double breasted coat; photograph imprinted Thuss, Koellein & Giers, Nashville, Tenn.

Thomas Washington Talley, Fisk University Chemistry professor, was also a pioneering African American folklorist. Born in Bedford County, Tennessee, to former slaves, Talley graduated from Fisk in 1890, and earned graduate degrees from Walden and Meharry Universities and the University of Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chattanooga street cleaners
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans
Street cleaning
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two African American males, in billed caps and boots, sweeping litter onto a shovel in front of a metal trash bin on wheels. The man at left, who wears some type of work coverall, appears to be smoking a pipe, while the man right wears a worn sweater with a hole at shoulder. A car parked at the curb around the corner is partially visible and a placard on the building behind the men reads "Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company."

These two street cleaners appear in a downtown setting, in front of a building with a clean stone facade and modern concrete sidewalk with stone curbing, at a time when it appears to be somewhat chilly and when no other persons were at the scene--possibly early morning. Although this is a public setting, work hours for African American menial laborers may have been restricted so they were virtually invisible to many of those who worked in this district.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Randolph Miller
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Judd, A.W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Media
African American newspaper editors; African Americans
Men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Randolph Miller, editor of the Chattanooga Blade, an African American newspaper.

Miller was a former slave who moved to Chattanooga from Georgia in October 1864. He worked as a pressman on several newspapers before starting his own paper, the Weekly Blade in 1898. The Blade ran for twelve years, and Miller became known for his condemnation of segregation. In 1905, Miller was one of the organizers in Chattanooga of the streetcar system in protest of a 1905 state law that segregated streetcar passengers. He started his own taxi service in 1905, the Hack Line, that ran between Chattanooga and outlying African American communities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leading themes used in Singing Negro Folk Rhymes
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Talley, Thomas
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Peforming Identity
Musicians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten musical notation and lyrics beginning with "Oh the Old Hen Cackled She."

Thomas W. Talley, who chaired the Chemistry Department at Fisk University for 25 years, was also a singer and a musician. In 1922, he published Negro Folk Rhymes, based on the stories, rhymes, and songs he learned in his youth, with his own scholarly analysis and an introduction by Vanderbilt literature professor Walter Clyde Curry. According to scholar Lucinda Poole Cockrell, Talley's volume was "the first serious collection of folksongs from Tennessee . . . and the first to be assembled by a black scholar." <http://tennesseeencyclopedia.net/entry.php?rec=1683>

Dick Poynor was born into slavery in Virginia in 1802, and moved to Williamson County in 1816. He obtained his freedom between 1850 and 1860. He operated a chair factory on his farm in western Williamson County. He and his son, James, produced hundreds of chairs during their careers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: J.C. Napier and two men at birthplace cabin
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
National Leaders
African Americans; African American businesspeople
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a rural scene, two men (J.C. Napier on right) standing in front of a double pen log cabin with saddlebag addition. Another man, who is also wearing a dark suit and white shirt like the others, stands next to the corner of addition. The laundry on the line suggests that the cabin is still inhabited.

James Carroll Napier was born on the western outskirts of Nashville in 1845. His parents, who were slaves at the time of his birth, were freed three years later. They sent James and his siblings to the school of Daniel Wadkins, a free black teacher whose students numbered as many as sixty. When a white backlash against free blacks caused the closure of the school, Napier's parents sent him to Ohio to complete his education. After graduating from Howard Law School in Washington, D.C. Napier returned to Nashville, became involved in Republican politics, and practiced law. He was elected to the City Council in 1878, was one of the founders of the National Negro Business League, and served as the appointed Register of the United States Treasury from 1911-1913.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Josh White: Complete recorded works 1940-1941 in chronological order
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: White, Josh (1914-1969)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
African American musicians; Sound recordings--Album covers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Album cover for reissue of Josh White recordings in 1940 and 19411.

The liner notes for this compilation of recordings, written by Dave Moore, indicate that Josh White's performances during this period, with both black and white performers of the day, including Billie Holiday and Pete Seeger, ranged from gospel to mainstream blues. They also earned him notoriety by combining familiar traditional melodies with protests against inequality for African Americans. White became so well-known that he was invited to perform for President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. He was also brought before Senator Joseph McCarthy's House Un-American Activities Committee, but managed to emerge from that encounter unscathed and continued to perform into the 1950s and 1960s.

Griggs Hall, located on the campus of American Baptist College, was built in 1924. The original building contained adminstrative offices, a library, classrooms, and a dormitory. The school served as a gathering place for many leaders in the Civil Rights Movement. The American Baptist Theological Seminary Historic District was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2013.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Zip Coon: A Popular Negro Song
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dixon, George W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Firth & Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scan of cover of Zip Coon: A Popular Negro Song.

The song Zip Coon was originally performed by George Washington Dixon in 1834 as a caricature of free, urban African American. He was portrayed as a well-dressed dandy who "put on airs" and pretended to be above his station. White audiences, confident in their social (and racial) superiority, were entertained by Zip Coon's misplaced attempts to seem clever, educated, and sophisticated. The tune used for the song will be familiar to contemporary listeners as "Turkey in the Straw."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Lodges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Grand Lodge United Brothers of Friendship and Sisters of the Mysterious Ten Lodge standing in front of the Shorter Chapel AME Church.

The United Brothers of Friendship and Sisters of the Mysterious Ten was a benevolent society first organized in 1861 in Louisville, Kentucky. After being disrupted by the Civil War, the group was reorganized in 1868 by William H. Gibson. The group offered sickness, disability and burial benefits to its members. The UBF had lodges throughout the nation, and national membership was 100,000 by 1892.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Iron scrollwork arch mounted on square stacked limestone pillars. "Mt. Ararat Cemetery" is spelled out in wrought iron lettering, with running scroll of decorative motifs below and surrounding the simple iron cross atop the arch.

Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Nashville was established in 1869 by two African American benevolent groups, the Sons of Relief No. 1 and the Colored Benevolent Society. Hundreds, if not thousands, of African Americans have been buried here since that time.

The Knights of Pythias of North and South America, Europe, Asia, and Africa is the African American counterpart of the white Knights of Pythias, and the group was established in 1869. The fraternal group had a number of lodges in Tennessee, and by 1920 there were more than 22,000 members of the group in the state.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rock of Ages CME Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-story, white, front gable building covered in simulated stone siding, with projecting front gable central entrance bay concrete block addition.

The first CME (Christian Methodist Episcopal, formerly Colored Methodist Episcopal) was Capers Memorial CME Church in Nashville, organized in 1866. In 1870, leaders from Capers and other African American Methodists in West Tennessee broke away from the Methodist Episcopal Church, South and created a new denomination, the CME church. The CME church was especially popular in West Tennessee, and was headquartered in Jackson, Tennessee until 1970, when the headquarters moved to Memphis. The CME Church has more than a million members.

The Volunteer Army Ammunition Plant was established in Chattanooga in 1941 to produce TNT for the war effort. The plant was reactivated during the Korean War, producing TNT until 1957. Production resumed in 1966 for the Vietnam War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James A. Henry and graduating class
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American students; African American school principals; African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Principal James A. Henry and members of the graduating class of Howard High School.

Although it had several early locations, possibly also including a church, before the construction of its own building on 9th Street, historian Rita Lorraine Hubbard [African American of Chattanooga: A History of Unsung Heroes, 2007] believes that Howard School may originally have been housed in a former federal hospital barracks on Chestnut Street. It was founded as a "free" school for African Americans circa 1865, and named for General O.O. Howard, a commissioner of the Freedmen's Bureau. By 1872, it had become the first public school (for either white or African American children) in Chattanooga. Professor James Henry, shown in this photograph, was the first African American principal of the school. A native of Buffalo, New York, he graduated from Atlanta University in 1883, came to Chattanooga to teach at Howard in 1884, and was present at the school's first graduation in 1886. He is surrounded in the photograph by members of the graduating class.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hatch, Steven D., Architect

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four-story brick building on limestone foundation. Gothic Revival-style stone arches over the windows, applied brickwork decoration, and pointed tower cupola.

Jubilee Hall was completed in 1876 on the campus of Fisk University, and was funded by the concerts given by the Fisk Jubilee Singers. It was the first permanent building built on the campus. Construction began in 1873, and the building was designed by architect Steven D. Hatch of New York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
College buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-story brick structure, with double arched windows, ornamental brick detailing and a white wooden bell tower cupola.

Anderson Hall, located on the campus of Maryville College, was built in 1870. Part of the funds used to build the building came from the Freedmen's Bureau. Maryville College was one of the first colleges in the United States to admit African Americans, Native Americans, and women, in addition to male students, as early as 1869.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Historic photograph of the Jefferson Street Church of Christ, located at Jefferson Street and 26th Avenue in Nashville.

During the early twentieth century, Nashville's Jefferson Street developed into a thriving African American community. Numerous African American businesses and churches were located in this area, and the area later became famous for its jazz and blues. This sanctuary for the Jefferson Street Church of Christ was built in 1927. The building was razed during urban renewal.

Leisure
Fairs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement, published in the Nashville Globe 23 July 1909, for the Second Annual Colored Fair.

Segregation extended to all aspects of life in Tennessee, including the fair. Several "colored fair associations" sprang up across the state, organizing fairs for local African Americans. This advertisement was for the Tennessee Colored Fair Association, of which James C. Napier was the president. The fair in 1909 was held in Greenwood Park, an African American park, in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hayes, Roland (1887-1977)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of a ten page "Press book for Roland Hayes,Tenor" with biographical information, critical reviews, and descriptions of notable performances. Hayes's management company's address and telephone, in Boston, Massachusetts, are listed at bottom.

According to the biographical information in this press book, Hayes first performed in New York City in 1917 at Aeolian Hall and had attracted an overflow crowd at Carnegie Hall in 1944. Among other honors, Hayes had been awarded an honorary doctorate in Music at Ohio Wesleyan, and a Doctor of Laws degree from Morehouse College. Special mention was made of the fact that he had performed at the Library of Congress at the 75th anniversary celebration of the Thirteenth Amendment in 1940.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Lodges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement, published in the Nashville Globe 30 April 1909, for an entertainment held by the Lightfoot Lodge No. 17 of the Knights of Pythias.

This advertisement shows that fraternal organizations held a number of different events for the larger, African American community. This event was to be held at the Odd Fellows Auditorium, a separate fraternal group. This also shows that fraternal groups worked together and allowed other groups to use their facilities as meeting spaces.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Valaida Snow
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
African American women singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of Valaida Snow, blues musician born in Chattanooga in c. 1903.

Valaida Snow was a blues singer and musician, and was known as the "Queen of the Trumpet" for her ability on that instrument. She became a professional musician by the age of 15, and spent much of the 1920s touring the United States with various musical reviews. She appeared in some feature films in the late 1930s, and toured Europe in 1939. While performing in Denmark, she was arrested by Nazis and may have spent nearly two years in a concentration camp (Wester-Faengler). After her release in a prisoner exchange, Snow returned to New York City and tried to regain fame as a musician. She died in 1956.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Certificate of Appointment, Governor W.G. Brownlow to J.C. Napier
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
National Leaders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stamped with the Great Seal of Tennessee on certificate bearing the legend "State of Tennessee" with an engraving of the Tennessee State Capitol at top center, this document, dated 25 April 1868, appoints J.C. Napier as County Claim Commissioner for Davidson County.

James C. Napier was born to free parents in Nashville in 1845. Young James attended a free black school in Nashville until the disruption caused by the Civil War. With the children of several other free black families, he went to Ohio to continue his education. On his return to Nashville, he heard an Emancipation Day speech by John Mercer Langston, a prominent Ohio free black and a friend of Napier's father, who visited Nashville on December 30, 1864. The young Napier became involved in local Republican politics, as this certificate of appointment to a post in the Reconstruction administration of Tennessee's Republican Governor, William Gannaway Brownlow, attests. At Langston's invitation, Napier left Nashville a year or so later to attend Howard Law School in Washington, D.C., from which he graduated in 1872.

Coney Island Park, a park "for colored people only," was located on Buena Vista Street near 10th Avenue North in Nashville. It opened in 1910 and offered weekly band concerts in addition to other amusements. However, it failed to be a success and closed in 1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maude Woodfork as "Aunt Jemima"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African American women; African American women in advertising
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Autographed photograph of Maude Woodfork in Aunt Jemima costume.

Maude Woodfork, a native of Wilson County, was born in 1892. She found professional success as an actress hired to represent the cook attired in apron and bandana on "Aunt Jemima" pancake mix packaging. She studied dramatic arts at Tennessee State University, worked for the WPA in Chicago teaching dramatics and made a career portraying this popular stereotype of a southern cook for Quaker Oats' brand "Aunt Jemima" pancake mix at a time when the popularity of packaged foods went hand in hand with broadcast advertising.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Handbill for an integrated performance
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
Advertising fliers; African American musicians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handbill for an integrated performance in 1942 in Eureka, Alabama.

Billed as "first time in history that white and colored render a joint program," handbill advertises an event at Eureka School, in Eureka, Alabama in 1942. The performers were the Daniel Quartet, a white gospel group featured on the Grand Ole Opry, and the Fairfield Four, an African American gospel group from Nashville. Sharing the bill, apparently, was boxer Joe Louis's mother. According to the Encyclopedia of American Gospel Music John Daniel (1903-1961), the leader of the quartet, was from the Sand Mountain area of Alabama. He moved the singing group to Nashville in the 1940s, which allowed broadcasts over WLAC and WSM radio. Joining John Daniel and his brother Troy over the years were a number of aspiring young singers, including Gordon Stoker (1924-2013), who joined the group as a pianist right out of high school. Stoker is best-known as a member of The Jordanaires, for whom he played piano beginning in 1950, assuming the role of first tenor in 1953 and continuing with the group until his retirement in 2000.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sitka School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sitka School was an African American school in rural Gibson County. It was built in 1942 by the community as a two-room frame building and had electrical wiring. The school was set on acres of land, and the community also donated a playground for the school. It is typical of the types of rural schools available to African Americans in Tennessee during this time period.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street School, Chattanooga
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-story brick building with triple stone arched entry, steep pitched roof with two front gable dormers, side gable dormer also visible on left side, and center steeple with gothic cupola. A low stone wall marks the boundary of the property and utility poles and wires are visible in front of the building. Photograph shows small bare trees out front, and a low modern-looking horizontal structure behind, with a square brick smokestack behind it. Written at lower left on the photograph "Main Street Colored School" and at lower right "Stokes."

Originally named Montgomery Avenue School, this photograph shows what became known as the Main Street School after Montgomery Avenue became Main Street. In 1881, this public school, originally housed in a church building, became the first in Chattanooga to have an African American teacher assigned to teach African American students. The circa 1890s building shown here was built to accomodate Chattanooga's growing African American population, as were East Fifth Street and East Eighth Street Schools.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Matt Gardner Homestead
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Dwellings; Historic buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two story frame building on stone foundation, with standing seam metal roof. A central doorway is flanked by two double hung windows and covered with a 3/4 width shed roof porch on stone pier blocks. Above the porch, an upper story features two 4/4 smaller, double hung windows.

Matt Gardner was born into slavery in 1847, and freed in 1865. A frugal man, Mr. Gardner saved his money until he was able to purchase a 300 acre farm on the Elk River in Giles County. In addition to his farm, he served as a pastor for two separate Baptist churches in the community, funded the community-built school, and led fundraising efforts in 1926 to build a Rosenwald School in his community. Mr. Gardner lived until the age of 95, a respected leader in his community. His homestead is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and the site is also home of the Matt Gardner Homestead Museum that interprets African American life. The house pictured here was built as a two-story saddlebag house in 1896.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Carroll Van West, photographer

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Historic photo in frame of Matt & Henrietta Gardner
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
African American women; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph of a man and a woman seated side by side in front of a white frame building is matted in light brown surrounded by a white spacer and a carved green frame. A figure standing behind them is obscured by the way the image has been divided by two openings in the mat. The bearded man seated at left is smiling, wearing a white shirt, bow tie, and dark suit and holding an open bible in both hands. The woman seated at right with her hands in her lap, has broad high cheekbones and a solemn expression. She wears a light colored hood and scarf, a dark dress, and a white apron.

Matt Gardner was born into slavery in 1847 in Alabama, and sold to Richard C. Gardner, a Nashville merchant and plantation owner in Elkton, Tennessee, in 1862. In 1877, he married Henrietta Jenkins. In the late 1880s, Matt Gardner financed and helped to build the first school for African Americans in Elkton, as well as providing room and board at his farm for the teacher. In addition to farming, Matt Gardner traveled around Giles County, Tennessee and Limestone County, Alabama, preaching at different churches on alternating Sundays. Henrietta and Matt were the parents of eleven children. Henrietta died on July 23, 1940. When Matt Gardner died June 5, 1943, more than 1,000 people attended his funeral.

Fort Oglethorpe Army Post served as a training facility for several different units during World War II. This photograph is labeled "Kathryn A. Wills, 1st Lt. W.A.C. Commanding, Co. 1, 20 Regt. Third W.A.C. Training Center, Fort Oglethorpe, GA, May 26, 1945."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville College Normal School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Browder, B.B.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American college students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Composite photograph of 12 men and 10 women. The letters K & C are at top, along with a 1912 pennant. At bottom are the words Motto, "Look on the Bright Side", Normal, Knoxvillel College, Knoxville Tenn signed B.B. Browder at lower right.

Knoxville College was formed to educate African American students from the elementary grades through college preparation for the teaching profession, hence the designation "Normal" school in this composite photograph. Professional schools in medicine and theology were added in the 1890s, as well as an industrial and vocational program that received support from the Freedmen's Bureau and public funding from the University of Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roger Williams University, Nashville, Tenn., academic class
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American college students
Men; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fourteen young men wearing suits, standing or seated, one young woman in high-collared long sleeved blouse and skirt standing at right

This photograph is one of at least sixteen images of African American businesses and homes in Nashville (several additional images of Fisk University and Roger Williams University students can be accessed here: http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/anedub/) that are part of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. 220 of the photographs are now in the collections of the Library of Congress, including 24 taken in Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1), Tennessee. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Colored Chauffers Club
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Professional Organizations
African Americans
Chauffeurs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of eleven men wearing billed caps and uniforms, flanked by two men in business suits.

Historian Robert J. Booker has identified the men in this group as follows: seated, left to right, Edgar Blair, Gaines Armbrister, unidentified, unidentified, John Walker; standing, left to right are, Dr. Luther Boyd, unidentified, Robert Martin, Lithcoe Cox, Mr. Montgomery, unidentified, unidentified, Dr. James Presnell. The two physicians were, apparently, sponsors of this professional society. Dr. M.L. Boyd practiced medicine in Knoxville from 1911 to 1933; Dr. James H. Presnell, who built a medical building at 503 East Vine Avenue in 1922, was active in Knoxville from 1913 to 1950.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Baptist Church, Beale Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: First Baptist Church, located at 379 Beale Street in Memphis, has been a part of Memphis's African American community since the congregation first erected a frame building on Beale Street in 1864. Beginning in 1866, the congregation began building this building, completing it in c. 1880. Former president Ulysses Grant visited the church in 1880. It is considered to be the first brick-constructed, multi-story church built by African Americans in the United States. After a fire in 1925, the interior was rebuilt, and the exterior was painted white in c. 1964.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dunbar Public School, a Rosenwald School in Loudon County.

Dunbar Public School was built as a Rosenwald School in c. 1923. It was the only African American school in the community, and served grands kindergarten through eighth. It closed with integration and now serves as a community center.

The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. Advertisements; African American baseball players

This advertisement, published in the Nashville Globe on April 23, 1909, was for a baseball game between two African American teams, the Birmingham Giants and the Nashville Collegians. Managed by Serk Smith, the Nashville Collegians traveled the region, playing teams in Kentucky, Alabama, Indiana, and Illinois.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Woodard's Studio, Detroit
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
African American singers
Gospel singers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of six men, posed in two rows of three.

The Fairfield Four, a gospel group from Nashville, became nationally known when the CBS network picked up their radio broadcasts for Nashville station WLAC. Pictured on the bottom row (left to right) are Sam McCrary, James S. Hill, George Gracie. Pictured on the top row (left to right) are Rufus Carrethers, Willie Frank Lewis, and Rev. Edward "Preacher" Thomas. The group originated in the 1920s in Nashville's Fairfield Baptist Church.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Advertisements; African Americans -- Funeral customs and rites; Undertakers and undertaking
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This ad, published in the Murfreesboro Union in 1933, is for H. Preston Scales. Preston Scales established his funeral home in Murfreesboro in 1916, and the funeral home is still in business. Mr. Scales also established the Helping Hand Mutual Burial Association, an association that provided each deceased member with a funeral benefit. Mr. Scales died in 1946. The ad was published in the Murfreesboro Union, an African American newspaper in Murfreesboro, published by Mary Ellen Vaughn from 1920-c. 1950.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Bottoms, Murfreesboro
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
African American neighborhoods
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of "The Bottoms," an African American neighborhood in Murfreesboro, Tennessee. It was destroyed by urban renewal and the building of Broad Street.

The Bottoms was located near the south-west section of downtown Murfreesboro, and developed as a blue-collar neighborhood during Reconstruction. Although some whites lived in the area, it was largely an African American neighborhood. The area often flooded due to its proximity to Lytle Creek.

Musicians
African American musicians; Musicians

Cecil Gant was a blues musician born in Nashville and recorded for Bullet Records. His hits included "Nashville Jumps" and "I Wonder." This image depicts Gant performing with white musicians for a recording session for WSM. The musicians are (left to right) Charley Grant, Farris Coursey, Jack Charamella, Ted Swinney, and Cecil Gant at piano.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doe Creek School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
School buildings; Log buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Doe Creek School, a one-room log school.

Doe Creek School, located a few miles south of Scotts Hill in Henderson County, served as a one-room school and church for generations. This log cabin, dating to c. 1870, is typical of the school buildings used across Tennessee by both white and African American children well into the 20th century. This served as a school until the 1950s. It is the last one-room school house in the region.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pullman blanket
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Transportation
Blankets
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Blanket used on Pullman Car trains by passengers.

Brown blankets, such as the one pictured here, were used by passengers on Pullman Train cars. When they became threadbare and deemed no longer fit for service, the brown blankets were dyed blue and given to Pullman porters. This ensured that white passengers would never accidentally receive a blanket used by an African American porter.

Knoxville College President John Scuoller McCulloch became president of the newly-formed Knoxville College in 1877. Two of his sons were enrolled at the school. McCulloch was a Presbyterian minister who had served as a chaplain in the Union Army during the Civil War.

African American iron and steel workers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five African American men (and possibly a white supervisor at front left) standing in large brick chamber, with arched doorways letting in outside light. Long cylindrical hollow rods are attached to metal racks, and one that appears to be a cast plaster "core" is being lifted at one end by a metal hook attached to a metal rod inserted in the end of the core.

The predecessor to the United States Pipe & Foundry Company, the Chattanooga Pipe and Foundry Works, was opened in 1877. Over the years the company consolidated with others to form the United States Pipe & Foundry company. Many of the company's workers, particularly during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, were African American.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Russell Goode, a music teacher at Howard High School in Chattanooga, accompanying Coretta Scott King as she sings.

Russell Goode was born in Chattanooga, and graduated from Howard High School in 1944. He received his B.A. in music from Fisk University in 1949, and an MA in music from Columbia University in 1959. In addition to teaching music at Howard Junior High School, Goode was a recognized accompanist, both for gospel singer Mahalia Jackson and for Coretta Scott King, widow of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Haselrig dairy milk deliveryman
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
African Americans
Milkmen & milkwomen; Trucks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A milk deliveryman and his car from the Haselrig Dairy. Haselrig Dairy was owned by an African American named C.D. Haselrig.

C.D. Haselrig opened Haselrig Dairy in the late 1920s, and he sold cheese and produce. In 1949, the dairy started processsing and delivering milk. It may have been the only African American owned dairy of its type in the South during this time period.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Iron Foundry Workers, United States Pipe & Foundry Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
African American Iron and steel workers; Iron industry and trade
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the foreground, two African American men wearing overalls hoist an iron flask. Railroad tracks run in between the two, and a spur track curves to go inside the gable-roofed brick building behind them. Other worker are present, stacks of iron pipe visible on site.

The predecessor to the United States Pipe & Foundry Company, the Chattanooga Pipe and Foundry Works, was opened in 1877. Over the years the company consolidated with others to form the United States Pipe & Foundry company. Many of the company's workers, particularly during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, were African American.

Historian Robert J. Booker has identified several of those in the open car on its way to the first Appalachian Exposition, which was held at Knoxville's Chilhowee Park in 1910, as follows: the young lady, front seat right, with parasol, (Mrs.) Bessie Settle (Richardson) and the young girl in the center as (Mrs.) Margaret Singleton (Carson). oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Julius Freed house
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
Historic buildings; Houses and homes
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Julius Freed House in Trenton was built in 1871 by Julius Freed, a Prussian-born Confederate veteran who moved to Trenton following the Civil War. A Jewish merchant, Julius Freed never fully assimilated in the dominant Southern culture. As their was no synagogue in Trenton, Freed allowed his home to be used by other Jewish residents of the community to hold observations of Jewish holidays and special occasions. Freed remained prominent in Trenton until his death in 1908.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Waiting for the bus at the Memphis terminal
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bubley, Esther, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Transportation
African Americans; Segregation
Bus terminals; Buses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph taken from a high vantage point of a mixed crowd of black and white passengers in the outdoor area of a bus terminal. In bay number 3 is a bus with a placard for Chattanooga. Visible above the heads of passengers is a sign for "White Waiting Room."

This image shows a crowd in the Memphis terminal, September 1943, during a Greyhound bus trip from Louisville, Kentucky, to Memphis, Tennessee. It was taken by Esther Bubley (1921-1998), a young photographer who had been hired by Roy Stryker, formerly at the Farm Security Administration, who had just been appointed to direct photography for the Office of War Information. Bubley spent four weeks riding buses on a route that include Pittsburgh, Indianapolis, Chicago, Columbus, Cincinnati, Louisville, Memphis, Nashville and Chattanooga before heading back to Washington. One of the reasons for the series was to document the increase in bus travel due to wartime rationing of gasoline and tires.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Soldier with children in yard in North Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Reverend L.O., photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
African Americans in military service; African American soldiers; African American children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white image of a smiling young African American soldier in uniform seated in a wooden lawn chair below a raised wooden porch and the corner of a frame house holds two tiny children in white dresses, with a seated boy about two years of age wearing shorts and holding a bottle leaning against the chair at his feet.

The Reverend Lonzie Odie Taylor (circa 1899-1977) was pastor of Olivet Baptist Church in Memphis in the 1930s, 1940s, and early 1950s. He was also a photographer who recorded the daily life of the community in which he lived. This informal family portrait of a smiling young soldier in uniform, seated in a lawn chair with three young children, in a neatly kept, middle class neighborhood with established trees and vegetation, has a friendly informality that suggests not only a moment of tranquility, stability, and prosperity, but also that the photographer was known and liked by the subject.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Soldier saluting in front of Taylor screen
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Reverend L.O., photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
African American soldiers; African Americans in military service
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white studio portrait of a slender African American man in uniform posed in front of a brush-stroked backdrop. The soldier wears a private first class chevron on his sleeve, as well as a medal on his chest.

The Reverend Lonzie Odie Taylor (circa 1899-1977) was pastor of Olivet Baptist Church in Memphis in the 1930s, 1940s, and early 1950s. He was also a photographer who recorded the daily life of the community in which he lived. Posed studio shots, such as this one, give evidence that his photographic output was of value to his subjects. Historically, soldiers in uniform have had portraits made for the purpose of recording patriotic service or creating a keepsake image for loved ones. Photographs might also be commissioned to record a military promotion or commendation. In this case, the soldier is wearing a medal, which indicates that he has performed meritorious service and possibly seen combat.

A photograph of his home and family appears to have been taken at the same time as this and at least two other photographs of successful African Americans living in Knoxville at the turn of the twentieth century. This is one of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway for display at the Paris Exposition of 1900. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. The Library of Congress holds 220 of the photographs, including 24 taken in Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1), Tennessee. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Zinc Company Negro Baseball League
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity; Claiming Space
Athletes; Work
African American baseball players
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twelve middle-aged African American men in plain baseball uniforms with baseball caps, posed in two rows (5 men standing, 7 men seated) out of doors.

The Zinc Company Baseball League, from Jefferson City, Tennessee, played in the old Negro League. According to the Tennessee Encyclopedia of History & Culture <http://tennesseeencyclopedia.net>,the first zinc mining in Tennessee occurred at Mossy Creek, near Jefferson City, in 1854. After the early surface mines were exhausted, the zinc industry developed large underground operations in Knox, Jefferson, Hawkins, Hancock, and Grainger Counties. The industry was one of the highest producers nationally in the 1960s, and its modern production depends on a small number of large operators around Mascot, in the Jefferson City area. The American Zinc Company came to Mascot in 1915. The East Tennessee Zinc Company is still producing in Jefferson City.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Chattanooga's "Red Light" District
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Maps
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn map showing location of various property owners on residential streets adjacent to a business district.

This map was used in the Supreme Court case of Weidner v Freeman, 1911, to support claim by plaintiff that some residences in the neighborhood, which was within several blocks of Chattanooga's African American business district, were being used for prostitution and therefore depressing real estate values. One of the assertions being made was that if the illegal activity continued, the neighborhood would continue to become marginalized to the extent that residential properties would only be saleable to African Americans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aaron Douglas mural in Cravath Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Douglas, Aaron
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
Mural painting and decoration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A black and white photograph showing a niche mural depicting a seated figure with suit, hat, and cane and a robed figure in a dramatic pose, holding a mask, in front of a backdrop of a tall column and several skyscraper-type buildings, above a card catalog cabinet in Cravath Hall, which formerly housed the library at Fisk University.

Aaron Douglas, born in Topeka, Kansas, in 1898, was one of the leading visual artists of the Harlem Renaissance. He was commissioned in 1930 to paint a series of murals in Cravath Hall at Fisk University. These murals depict African American contributions to American history and society. He returned to Fisk University as a professor in the late 1930s and founded the Art Department. Douglas died in Nashville in 1979.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawing of exterior of Fisk Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
College buildings; Fisk University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A drawing of the Fisk University Library, designed by architect Henry Hibbs.

Cravath Hall was built in 1929-1930, and it initially served as the library for Fisk University. It was designed by Nashville architect Henry Hibbs, and is named for the first president of Fisk, Erastus M. Cravath. The first classes at Fisk began on January 9, 1866, and Fisk University was incorporated on August 22, 1867. Hibbs also designed Scarritt College in Nashville, the University of Tulsa library, Neely Auditorium and Alumni Memorial Hall on the Vanderbilt University Campus.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James C. Napier
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Professional Organizations
African Americans; African American businesspeople
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James C. Napier was born to free parents in Nashville in 1845. He received a law degree from Howard University in 1872. He served on the Nashville City Council between 1878 and 1886, and was President William Taft's Register of the United States Treasury from 1911 to 1913. He served as president of the National Negro Business League, and was one of the founder's of One Cent Savings Bank. This bank, now known as the Citizens Savings Bank, has been in business since 1904. He also served on the boards of Fisk University and Howard University. He died in 1940 and is buried in Nashville's Greenwood Cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bijou Theatre
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: International Post Card Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
Theaters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard of the Bijou Theater in Nashville, an African American entertainment venue for roughly forty years.

The Bijou Theater was located at 423 4th Avenue North in Nashville. Built in 1904, in 1916 it became one of the South's leading African American theaters. In 1918, African Americans held their own celebrations marking the end of World War I at the Bijou. It was razed in 1957-1958 to build Municipal Auditorium. The Bijou was operated by the Bijou Amusement Company, and one of the first managers was Milton Starr, a white man.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville College Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical Profession
African Americans -- Hospitals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-story brick building with a pyramid roof, central dormer window, double hung windows with slightly arched sashes, two brick chimneys, and central entry through a front porch supported by four classical order columns. The building appears to have a side addition of similar brick construction, with front porches on both levels across the width of the building. A utility pole stands on the street out front and wires are visible running to the buildings.

Knoxville College established a medical school in 1895 to train physicians and also to provide medical care for African Americans. The school struggled with inadequate staffing and facilities and closed in 1900 after graduating only two students: N.B. Crenshaw and J.G. King. Recognizing the ongoing need for professional medical education, Dr. Henry Morgan Green, a graduate of Knoxville College with a degree from Northwestern University, was one of the founders of the Knoxville Medical College that same year. In its ten years of operation, the school prepared twenty-one doctors for the profession. However the need for a hospital continued--the Knoxville General Hospital opened in 1902 provided only two basement wards for African Americans and prohibited black physicians from attending patients. Eliza B. Wallace left money to Knoxville College to build a hospital on the campus as a facility to train nurses. The modern two-story building that opened in 1907 was built by Knoxville College students and constructed using student-made bricks. The wing for contagious diseases was added in 1915. Not only did it provide a well-equipped training facility for nurses, the hospital attracted more African American physicians to Knoxville. When the hospital closed in 1926, there were twenty black doctors in Knoxville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville College nurses on hospital porch
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical Profession
African American nurses; African American women; African Americans -- Hospitals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four young African American women and a white woman wearing nurses cap and white uniform, standing on a porch next to a column, with grapevine at left.

The Knoxville College Hospital was built with funds left by Eliza B. Wallace in a will to Knoxville College. The modern facility filled a need in the community for professional nursing instruction, provided medical care to Knoxville College students, and was open to outside patients. Private physicians were able to practice there as well, which helped make Knoxville a center for African American health care in the early decades of the twentieth century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Summer resort ad
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
Advertisements; African Americans; Summer resorts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for a summer resort for African Americans in Shelbyville.

This ad, published in the Nashville Globe on April 2, 1909, is for a summer resort taking place in Shelbyville, Tennessee. During segregation, travel was as segregated as the rest of society. This ad claims that the only resort for African Americans in the state would be open on the grounds of Turner Normal School in Shelbyville. Turner Normal College was established by the AME Church in Shelbyville in 1886 as a high school and relocated to Memphis in 1935.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vine Avenue Service Station
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Transportation
Service stations; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A number of African American men, many in chauffeurs caps and one in what appears to be a policeman's uniform, posed alongside two early automobiles, behind a two story frame house, and next to a one story building with tile roof overhang, cylindrical gas pump with lozenge-shaped orb reading "motor fuel" and free-standing marquee with logo and "That Good Gulf Gasoline. Supreme Motor Oil". An advertisement for Dunlop Tires is painted on back wall.

The Vine Avenue Service Station was one of several black-owned service stations located in the heart of the African American business district of Knoxville, along with at least three hotels, a number of taxi cab companies, several funeral homes and mortuaries, three drug stores, and other businesses serving the African American community.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Henry Morgan Green
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical Profession
African American physicians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handsome gentleman about thirty years of age, with mustache, with hands crossed at wrists, wearing collarless shirt, suit coat and vest, loosely knotted tie with tie pin, cufflinks, and watch chain.

Dr. Henry Morgan Green, a Georgia native who had graduated from Knoxville College before taking his medical degree at Northwestern University, was a physician in Knoxville from 1900 to 1939. He was one of the founders of Knoxville Medical College (1900-1910) and built his own two story medical building at 123 East Vine Avenue in 1922. During his career, he served as president of the National Medical Association and was one of the founders of the National Hospital Association.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hubbard Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical Profession
African Americans -- Hospitals; Meharry Medical College
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This photograph of a brick building on a stone foundation shows the original two-story Meharry hospital building to which has been added a third floor with a 1925 date plaque.

Hubbard Hospital, named for the first president of Meharry Medical College, George W. Hubbard was fully completed and dedicated on November 29, 1912. It served as the teaching hospital for Meharry Medical College. Meharry Medical College began in 1876 as the medical school of Central Tennessee College, established by the Freedmen's Aid Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bluff Furnace
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
Furnaces; Iron industry and trade
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print from stereoscope of the Bluff Furnace (Tennessee River Bluff Iron Works).

The East Tennessee Iron Manufacturing Company was incorporated in 1847, and was an important part of the iron and railroad industry. The Bluff Furnace began operation in 1856. In May 1860, it was converted to a coke-fueled furnace. In November 1860, it failed during operations, and the furnace was demolished.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hickman, Hester
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
Songsters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pamphlet sold by Benjamin Singleton with lyrics advertising the emigration to Kansas. The lyrics were written by Mrs. Hester Hickman of Nashville.

This "songster" or pamphlet of song lyrics, was sold by Benjamin Singleton. The lyrics, written by Hester Hickman of Nashville, advertised the emigration to Kansas. The lyrics to "The Land That Gives Birth to Freedom" note the hard conditions in Tennessee for the formerly enslaved and affirm the desire of African Americans to enjoy a peaceful home life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Helen Mae Lennon Hospital record book
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lennon, Edgar F.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical Profession
African Americans -- Hospitals; Medical records
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten entries on patient admissions and care from day one, January 6, 1923.

Dr. Edgar F. Lennon was the owner and operator of the Helen Mae Lennon Hospital on Clinch Street, which had twenty-five beds and also a training facility for nurses. This ledger contains notes on various patients signed by Lennon, as well as S(amuel) M. Clark, another prominent early physician in Knoxville.Lennon practiced medicine from 1917 to 1966. Clark was one of the founders of the East Tennessee Hospital Association in 1929, the group largely responsible for beginning a movement to found a separate "Negro Unit" at Knoxville General Hospital. The wing was completed in 1933, with funding from the Rosenwald Fund, the City of Knoxville, Knox County, and the East Tennessee Hospital Association.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mt. Zion AME Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gardner, Leigh Ann, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mt. Zion AME Church in Centerville, Tennessee is a good example of the small, historic African American churches that still dot the rural landscape in Tennessee. The church has been a vibrant part of the community, hosting both religious services and allowing African American fraternal groups to use the building. In the 1880s, the church started a high school for African Americans. Classes met at the church, and the school was known as the Centreville Male and Female Academy.

Military Service
War bonds and funds; Women; TNT (Chemical)

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Cemeteries
African American cemeteries; Sepulchral monuments
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mt. Olivet Cemetery, an African American cemetery, was established in Jackson in 1885. The establishment of this cemetery in 1885 shows the move towards Jim Crow segregation following Reconstruction in Tennessee, as the divisions between the races became more marked as the 19th century waned. More than 1600 people are buried in this cemetery. This marker for F.E. Grimes is one of several handmade markers found in this cemetery.

The male driver and a female passenger in the back seat are also wearing hats. The car's windshield is covered with decals.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The congregation of St. Mark's Presbyterian Church in Rogersville was established circa 1875. The church was closely associated with Swift Memorial Junior College, founded in 1883 by The Reverend Dr. William H. Franklin. The property for the church was purchased circa 1885 by the Board of Missions for Freedmen to add to the campus. Reverend Franklin, who was also pastor of St. Mark's Presbyterian, was a native of Knoxville and the first African American graduate of Maryville College. This building was erected circa 1912, the same year that St. Mark's Presbyterian received its charter from the State of Tennessee. It stands today, at the corner of Kyle and N. Hasson Streets, just one block north of West Main Street in downtown Rogersville. The congregation disbanded in 2002.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Photograph by Carroll Van West, courtesy of the Center for Historic Preservation, Middle Tennessee State University.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dining Room at the Matt Gardner Homestead
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Dwellings; Dining rooms
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A plank table with six ladder back chairs sits in front of a double hung window in a room with unpainted wooden walls and wood floor. The table is set with blue and white china and a glass oil lamp.

The Matt Gardner Homestead interprets African American history as well as agricultural history. The dining room, pictured here, shows some of the items that a prosperous farmer such as Matt Gardner would have owned. Matt Gardner was so successful that he was able to make loans to other farmers, both African American and white.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Douglas, Aaron
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
Mural painting and decoration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A silhouetted figure kneels on a platform with a microscope at his feet and a flashlight pointed at the heavens in his left hand. His right hand rests against a classical column, and planets and stars are visible in the sky behind him.

This section of the Cravath Library mural cycle, depicting the achievements of African Americans in scientific endeavors, is in the card catalog room. In 1930, popular Harlem Renaissance artist Aaron Douglas, was commissioned to create a cycle of murals depicting African American progress. The series of images he created for the library's two large reading rooms depict the transition from Africa to America and the building of America into a modern nation. He also painted vignettes, such as this one, in the niches over the card catalog and designs for the vaulted ceilings overhead.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flagg Grove School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the Flagg Grove School, a front-gable, unpainted, frame building, now relocated to the grounds of the West Tennessee Delta Heritage Center, Brownsville,Tennessee

The Flagg Grove School was an African American school formerly located in Nutbush, iThe Flagg Grove School was an African American school formerly located in Nutbush, in Haywood County. It was moved to Brownsville, Tennessee in 2012 and restored with help from the owners of the farm on which it stood for over one hundred years. This school was the childhood school of Tina Turner (born Anna Mae Bullock). Flagg Grove School was built on land purchased in 1889 from former slave Benjamin Flagg, who was Bullock's great uncle. The school was closed in 1968, and is a good example of the one-room schoolhouses used by African American children across the state well into the late 1960s. The building is now located at the West Tennessee Delta Heritage Center in Brownsville, Haywood County.n Haywood County. It was moved to Brownsville, Tennessee in 2012. This school was the childhood school of Tina Turner. Flagg Grove School was originally built on land purchased from former slave Benjamin Flagg in 1899. Flagg was a great uncle of Tina Turner. The school was closed in 1968, and is a good example of the one-room schoolhouses used by African American children across the state well into the late 1960s. The building is now located at the West Tennessee Delta Heritage Center in Brownsville, Haywood County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This advertisement from the September 17, 1909 edition of the Nashville Globe is for Turner Normal School in Shelbyville, Tennessee. This school, founded circa 1886 by the AME Church, was originally called Shelbyville High School. The name was changed to Turner Normal and Industrial in 1896 and later changed to Turner Normal School. It was moved to Memphis in 1935.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two rows of African American men wearing formal attire and fez hats with "Keblah" on them. The first row contains 8 men, either seated or kneeling on one knee; the second row has 8 standing men in the same attire, with 2 additional men wearing business suits and hatless on either end. The setting for this photograph is an interior space, with a draped window niche at back. A label with handwritten indentification " Dr. C.S. Boyd Illustrious Potentate Keblah Temple #78" has been placed over the image.

This photograph, which was taken in the Keblah Temple in Knoxville, Tennessee, includes Dr. C. S. Boyd, a Knoxville dentist, wearing round wire-rimmed glasses and seated fourth from left in the front row.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Free Hill School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Free Hill Rosenwald School was built c. 1929-1930 with assistance from the Julius Rosenwald Foundation. The only Rosenwald school built in Clay County, it operated as a school until 1966. It currently serves as a community center. The community of Free Hill is located five miles northeast of Celina, Tennessee, and was organized by former slaves. Virginia Hill, a slaveholder originally from North Carolina, freed her slaves and gave them 2,000 acres of land. The former slaves named their community Free Hill.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lincoln Rosenwald School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; African American students; African American school principals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Historic photograph of the Lincoln School, which has been inscribed with name and date, and listing of students and principal E. Angel (back row).

Beginning in 1912, the Rosenwald Fund contributed matching funds for the construction of thousands of schools for African Americans across the South. Built in 1925, the Lincoln School is an excellent example of the standardized architecture of the schools that were specified in the Community School Plans. The Rosenwald Fund provided $900 for the construction of the Lincoln School, Pikeville's African American community provided $1,200, Bledsoe County and the State of Tennessee provided $3236 for its construction.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Golden Hill Cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Cemeteries
African American cemeteries; Sepulchral monuments
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Golden Hill Cemetery in Clarksville dates to 1863, and may be the oldest tract of land continuously owned by African Americans in Clarksville. Stephen Cole, a former slave, purchased the land in 1863, and the cemetery was formally incorporated in 1882. A number of veterans are buried at Golden Hill, including Stephen Cole's son, Edward. Part of the significance of this site is that it is associated with the establishment of a distinct African American community in Clarksville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joseph Delaney, Self-Portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Delaney, Joseph
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
African American artists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders, three-quarter facing portrait of a handsome young man with dark, short cropped hair, wearing a dark suit, white shirt, and red tie. Signed lower left: Jos. Delaney 1933.

Artist Joseph Delaney (1904-1991) was born in Knoxville. His older brother Beauford also became quite well-known as an artist. Joseph studied at the Art Students League in New York and lived and worked in the city until his return to Knoxville in 1986. He served as an artist in residence at the University of Tennessee during the final years of his life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Southeast of Moccasin Bend
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Carothers, Rice
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
Watercolor painting, American
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scene depicts Moccasin Bend, on the Tennessee River, just outside the city of Chattanooga.

Rice Carothers was born in Chattanooga in 1909, and worked as an elevtor operator at the Times building. A graduate of Howard High School, Carothers was encouraged in his artistic endeavors by Chattanooga librarian Nora Crimmins. Adolph Ochs, publisher of the Times, noticed his talent. Carothers was sent to art school in New York in the 1930s. Carothers served in World War II, and died in Chattanooga in 1997. He donated seven of his watercolors to the Chattanooga Public Library as well as an oil painting of Judge Will Cummings.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: York Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This 2006 photograph shows the substantial two story brick school building, with its steep gable roof, central bay entrance door, and flat-roofed addition, in disrepair. The building has since been stablized and renovated.

World War I hero Alvin Cullum York founded the York Institute in 1926. He went on speaking tours to raise funds to provide the education he had never had, growing up in rural Fentress County, Tennessee, for the boys and girls of coming generations. The school was transferred to the state of Tennessee in 1937. The future of the York Institute was in peril for several years until a successful fund-raising campaign and the efforts of historians and preservationists made it possible to restore the building to use. Today it serves as a public K-12 school in the region.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Souvenir program, Cotton Makers Jubilee, inside cover
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: C&T Press Service, Memphis, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African American business enterprises; Parades
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Inside front cover and introductory page of the 1937 souvenir program for the Cotton Makers Jubilee. The inside cover contains two advertisements: the top 1/4 page was taken by A. Schwab, 163 Beale, "better goods at better prices" and the lower 3/4 page by Mid-South Refrigerator & Appliance Co. 206 Hernando Street, billing itself as "Memphis' Only Colored Appliance Store."

The introduction to the 1937 program recounts the history of the Cotton Makers Jubilee, which was founded by Dr. R.Q. Venson as the "Cotton-Makers Fiesta" in 1936, featuring a parade, a play about African American accomplishments, and a grand ball at which W.C. Handy performed as guest of honor. The name was changed to Cotton Makers Jubilee in 1937, and it became the African American counterpart to Memphis's Cotton Carnival. The objective of the "Memphis Cotton-Makers (sic) Jubilee as set out here" is to symbolize the great and important part which the colored people of this area have played in the history of cotton . . . it marks one of the first times in the history of this area . . . that colored and white Memphians and Delta citizens have been united in a common program for the advancement and development of their common home community--the Deep South--the cotton belt."
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library and Information Center

The Cotton Makers Jubilee, which officially began in 1937, was the African American version of Memphis's Cotton Carnival. The two festivals were concurrent and in later years some of the ceremonial events featured their honorary kings and queens appearing together.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Thomas Elsa Jones, President of Fisk University from Werthan Bag Company President Joe Werthan
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Werthan, Joe
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Correspondence; Donations
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed letter on Werthan Bag Company letterhead, signed by Joe Werthan.

Joe Werthan was a member of a prominent Jewish family that owned a large burlap bag manufacturing plant near the Fisk University campus. This letter accompanied a substantial monetary donation to Fisk University for a national summer project sponsored by the Society of Friends to outfit and renovate a school for African Americans in Whiteville, a town located in one of the most heavily populated post-slavery sections of southwest Tennessee during the height of Jim Crow segregation with its pronounced inequality of public educational facilities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Negro Homes -- Home of R.R. Church, Memphis, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white photograph shows a Victorian, cross-gable, two-story frame house with fancy Craftsman detailed pediments in double front gables, fancy lightning rods atop all visible gable peaks, and a brick chimney. The house is approached by terraced steps and a central sidewalk leading to the front door inside an enclosed porch. There are two trees on either side of the sidewalk, and a neat lawn surrounded by a low iron fence around the lot. A utility pole and wires are visible in front of the house.

This photograph, which was captioned, for purposes of display at the Paris Exposition of 1900, as "Negro Homes--home of R.R. Church, Memphis, Tenn. (exterior)" is one of at least twenty-four of African American businesses and homes in Tennessee that are part of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway. Robert Reed Church and his son Robert Reed Church, Jr., were two of Memphis's most prominent African American citizens. Church built a park and auditorium for on six acres of land on Beale Street in 1899. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. 220 of the photographs are now in the collections of the Library of Congress, including 24 taken in Tennessee: Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1). The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there. http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/anedub/
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D.C.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This black and white drawing shows a white woman holding the hand of a child walking on the sidewalk in front of a two-story frame house towards a flag pole and American flag flying out front. The house has brick chimneys on either end, a side addition with brick chimney, and is surrounded by a picket fence. Scribbled lines depict utility wires, trees in the front yard, clouds in the sky, and with a 1930s-era automobile parked on the street in front. Partially visible at lower left is a car parked on the side street and a white man wearing a hat.
Artist Joseph Delaney 1904-1991) moved to New York in 1930 and lived and worked there for many years. He may have made this drawing on a visit home to Knoxville, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: G.W. Franklin Funeral home
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A black hearse drawn by two white horses stands facing a single white horse harnessed to a black open-top buggy whose driver wears a bowler hat, in front of a frame building with G.W. Franklin, Undertaker. painted on its side. There is another horse-drawn hearse standing behind the one at center of the image, and an electric pole visible at left. A canvas awning appears to have been drawn up above the door of the business.

Born in Georgia, G.W. Franklin moved his funeral business to Chattanooga in 1894, and was the first African American funeral director and embalmer in Chattanooga. Franklin was a friend of Booker T. Washington and a member of the National Negro Business League. The funeral home remains in business, and is operated and owned by Franklin's descendants. Another image of G.W. Franklin's funeral home was included in the Paris Exposition of 1900, as part of an exhibit organized by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway.

oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: C&T Press Service, Memphis, Tennessee

Leisure
Festivals; African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Orange paper with black border and type, "Souvenir Program of the Cotton Makers Jubilee, Church Park Auditorium, May 12, 13, 14, 1937" with a photographic image at lower center, and a tribute to ..."Mr. R.R.Church, Dean of Beale Street, who by his encouragement has helped us to make a success of this year's Jubilee..." below.

This is the first year of the Cotton Makers Jubilee, which had evolved from the "Colored Jubilee Committee" in 1935, to the "Cotton-Makers Fiesta" in 1936, before it was officially named the Cotton Makers Jubilee in 1937. It was the African American version of Memphis's Cotton Carnival. The two festivals were concurrent and in later years some of the ceremonial events featured their honorary kings and queens appearing together.

Several of the African American passengers, including the front-most woman, a man two rows behind her, and the man seated in the center of the bench seat, look directly at the photographer, the white woman and man in first rows are not in focus, and another white woman looks away and out of the window.
"Jim Crow" public bus in Chattanooga, Tennessee, showing segregation of passengers: whites in front, blacks in back, and stenciled sign stating that the back of the bus was for the "Colored Race."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group of African American adults, some seated at banquet table, some turned to form a front row facing the camera. Inscribed: Made for Lt. G.W. Lee, Jr., Atlantic Life Ins. Co. on Beale

This group of nicely dressed men and women may have been gathered for a public or professional meeting in the cafeteria of Booker T. Washington High School, a public school for African Americans in Memphis. The inscription indicates that the photograph was ordered by George W. Lee, Jr., a World War I veteran and insurance executive active in Memphis politics. Lee, who earned the rank of 1st Lieutenant, continued to use the title professionally. The George W. Lee postal station at 826 Mississippi, was the first in Memphis to be named for an African American.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four young African American women in high collared blouses are seated around an African American gentleman in a suit whose arms rest on ornately carved arms of a chair.

According to historian Robert J. Booker, Austin High School only went through tenth grade until 1920, when the eleventh grade was added. In 1936, the school added twelfth grade. This group of four young women and one man could be either teachers or students.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John W. Manning, Principal, Austin High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Public Education
African American school principals
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Close up of young African American man wearing a dark jacket, white shirt, and tie.

Yale educated, John W. Manning was the first African American principal of Austin High School. Funds to build the city's first African American secondary school were raised by Emily Austin, a white Philadelphian who had moved to Knoxville to teach black children in 1870. The school, located at 327 Central Avenue, opened in 1879. Manning served as principal from 1881-1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Group of African American men in front of the County Clerk's office
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Morgan, John
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
African Americans; Trials
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The defendants in the Columbia Race Riot trial standing in front of the County Clerk's office after the verdict in the case was reached.

Future Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall came to Tennessee and headed the defense of the African Americans charged in connection with the Columbia Race Riot. He was assisted in his efforts by Z. Alexander Looby of Nashville and Maurice Weaver of Chattanooga. Marshall and his team were successful in having the judge move the trial from Columbia to Lawrenceburg, and the jury there acquitted 23 of the men and found two of the men guilty on October 4, 1946. On November 18, 1946, one of the two found guilty was acquitted; the other man received a commuted sentence.
