oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Myles Horton and Eleanor Roosevelt
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Civic Engagement
Horton, Myles, -- 1905-1990; Roosevelt, Eleanor, -- 1884-1962
Men; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eleanor Roosevelt and Myles Horton, principal founder of the Highlander Folk School.

Tennessean Myles Horton was one of those who established the Highlander Folk School in Grundy County in 1932. The school offered residential workshops on issues such as labor education, literacy training, leadership development and voter education. Workshops at Highlander were biracial. In the 1950s, the Highlander Center would also become a training ground for a number of Civil Rights Movement workers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Group of people on the courthouse square
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
Automobiles; Courthouses; Men; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of people standing amidst the scene of violence on the courthouse square in Athens, Tennessee.

On August 1, 1946, a group of veterans in Athens took up arms to stop a local group, led by State Senator Paul Cantrell and linked to Memphis mayor Edward Crump from stealing the election. The veterans broke into the courthouse and demanded the return of the ballot boxes. The deputies refused and the veterans opened fire. This "Battle of Athens" lasted several hours and only ended after the front of the jail was dynamited. The mob also turned cars over on the Square and burned them, as seen in this picture. The Battle of Athens was a victory for the veterans as the Election Commission swore in the veteran candidates as duly elected.

Wilson was the volume's editor, as indicated by a note at the bottom of the opening essay, by Dr. Henry Morgan Green, on page 4. Other pages of the booklet are available as part of the digital collections of the McClung Historical Collection, Knox County Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Group of jailed agitators
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
Civil disobedience
Jails; Men; Prisoners
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of several young men arrested for their part in the "Battle of Athens" on August 1, 1946.

Local politics in Athens, Tennessee was controlled in 1946 by the Cantrell-Mansfield ring. Former sheriff Paul Cantrell and current McMinn County sheriff Pat Mansfield led a corrupt ring that colluded with bootleggers, engaged in election chicanery, and "shook down" tourists and local residents for fees. In the August 1946 elections, World War II veterans supported the candidacy of one of their fellow veterans, Knox Henry, to push reform efforts. Sheriff Mansfield and his deputies physically intimidated several of the GIs, as well as an African American man attempting to vote, locking the ballot boxes inside the jail. This triggered the "Battle of Athens," in which veterans took weapons from the armory and fired on the deputies. After a day of violence, the ballot boxes were surrendered by deputies inside the jail. This event exemplifies veteran activism in local communities following World War II. The Columbia Race Riot, in February 1946, which ended in several deaths and widespread destruction in the African American business district in Columbia, Tennessee, was also prompted by a returning serviceman demanding fair treatment and the creation of a new social order in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville College Chemistry Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Public Education
African American college students; African American universities and colleges; African American men; African American women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Coeducational class of African American students standing at laboratory benches in a brick walled room, with a shelf holding clear glass bottles at rear, and a white man in a suit to the left of blackboard.

In the 1890s, when Knoxville College had a medical department, chemistry had been part of the medical curriculum. This modern laboratory, providing instruction in chemistry for students of the 1940s, may have been under the auspices of the University of Tennessee's faculty, per the continuing agreement to provide state-funded equal educational opportunity on separate campuses for African American Tennesseans. It was likely housed in the Mechanical and Industrial Building, or in the Agriculture Building, both of which were brick structures.

Washington, but the students shown here are dressed more like young scholars than aspirants to the laboring class.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Civic Engagement
African American judges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A portrait photograph of William Henry Hastie appears on the cover of Crisis Magazine.

William H. Hastie (1904-1976) who was born in Knoxville, graduated from Amherst College and Harvard Law School. Hastie was the first African American appointed to a federal judgeship. He served first in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where he later became as governor. In 1949, President Harry Truman selected him for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Blair T. Hunt
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hooks Brothers
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
African American soldiers; African Americans in military service; World War, 1914-1918
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Formal studio portrait of Lt. Blair T. Hunt in WW I uniform, with Chaplain's Corps insignia on collar.

Hunt served in France during WWI with the Chaplain's Corps. The college educated Hunt served as Principal of Booker T. Washington High School and as Pastor of the Mississippi Boulevard Christian Church, all the while working for opportunity for African Americans. He was a founder of the Memphis Urban League and the "Negro" YMCA.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Johnson fight ad
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Athletes
Advertisements; Boxers; Boxers, African American; Boxing matches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Big Detail" advertisement, inviting "colored people only" to the Ryman Auditorium, July 4, 1910, to hear "the best caller in Nashville" on the Johnson-Jeffries Prize Fight.

The match between Jack Johnson, an African American, and James Jeffries, a white former heavyweight boxing champion, was hailed as "The Fight of the Century." Johnson, to the surprise of the white media, won the match handily. The advertisement is for an event the day of the fight at the Ryman Auditorium. It shows that the Ryman Auditorium was used by African Americans for a number of events during the period of segregation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Baptist Church East Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Former slave Rev. Randall B. Vandavall founded the First Baptist Church East Nashville in 1866. The church was known as Vandavall's Baptist Church for many years, becoming officially chartered as First Baptist Church East Nashville in 1882. The current building, seen here, was built in 1928. The congregation played a role in the Civil Rights Movement, with members and leaders taking part in meetings and activities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Baptist Church Lauderdale
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: First Baptist Church, Lauderdale, is considered one of the most significant African American churches in Memphis and in West Tennessee. The congregation was begun in 1854 by Morris Henderson. This congregation built the First Baptist Beale church building. The congregation split in 1894, and the First Colored Baptist Church, as it was known, moved out of their church building on Beale Street to Zion Hall, also located on Beale Street. In 1906, the congregation moved to a site on St. Paul Avenue. In the 1930s, the area was condemned and the neighborhood demolished. At that time, the congregation moved to South Lauderdale Street, building the church building depicted here. The church enjoyed a long association with Booker T. Washington High School, an African American high school located across the street. This congregation is considered the "mother church" for many of the African American Baptist congregations in Memphis and West Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fredonia Baptist Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions
African American churches
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Although the current building for the Fredonia Baptist Church dates to 1957, this congregation dates to 1867, and has been an active church since its inception. Two Baptist ministers, Reverend Hardin Smith and Reverend Henry Owen, officially began this congregation in 1869 when they began organizing men and women to build a sanctuary at this location. The congregation met in a brush arbor until a frame structure could be built. The frame church was destroyed in a fire in 1899. The next building, built in 1900, was demolished in 1957 to make room for the current building. The Fredonia Baptist Church also served as a school, known as the Fredonia School.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Knoxville College Agriculture Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Public Education
African American universities and colleges; Knoxville College (Knoxville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-story, five bay, brick building with pyramid hip roof and three chimneys.

Even though Knoxville College was a private school, in 1891 the school contracted with the University of Tennessee to provide "separate but equal" industrial education for African Americans in lieu of their attending the publicly funded state university. The money appropriated by the University of Tennessee could be used only for faculty, students, and equipment, not for buildings or land. While the Freedmen's Bureau had furnished funds for a mechanical and industrial building in 1892, it was the citizens of Knoxville who donated money for the construction of the brick agricultural building in 1905. Knoxville College owned a 78-acre farm with a small herd of dairy cattle, and was a local leader in food production and teaching home skills.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Group of African Americans being transferred to jail in Nashville
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Military Service
African Americans; Riots
Firearms; Jails; Men; Police
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of African Americans being transferred to Nashville for safety during the Columbia Race Riot of 1946. Armed police line the outside of the jail with weapons drawn.

The Columbia Race Riot took place in Columbia, Tennessee on the night of February 25-26, 1946. An African American U.S. Navy veteran became involved in an altercation with a white store clerk. Arrested and charged initially with disturbing the peace, James Stephenson, was later charged with intent to commit murder. Released on bond, Stephenson returned home and a white mob gathered at the Maury County Courthouse. By the end of the night, two African American men were killed while in police custody, the entire African American business district had been ransacked by whites, weapons had been confiscated from African Americans, and African Americans were arrested without warrants. More than 100 African Americans were arrested, and none were granted bail or allowed legal counsel.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stokes (photographer?)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
African Americans -- Employment
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American workmen inside a large wooden truss structure, with clerestory windows and back windows providing light. Some are shown with two wheeled carts laden with stacks of parts, others are standing on either side of a long worktable with tools, or stacking and moving parts. A slender white man wearing a short collarless jacket and flat cap stands at center with his hands behind his back. Written on the photograph at lower center is "American Breake (sic) Shoe F'd'y" and "Stokes" at lower right.

The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company was established in 1902 in New Jersey. The company had manufacturing plants in Chattanooga; Buffalo, NY; Burnside, IL; Chicago, IL; Erie, PA; Baltimore, MD and many other cities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Field recording of the Fairfield Four, recorded by John Work III.

In 1941, John Work III recorded the Fairfield Four gospel quartet at the Fairfield Baptist Church in Nashville. The group went on to have a long, successful career as radio performers on WLAC, GRAMMY winners and also appeared in the popular film, "Oh Brother Where Art Thou."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville Globe front page
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Globe Pub. Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Media
African American newspapers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The front page of the Nashville Globe, an African American newspaper published in Nashville, Tennessee during the first half of the twentieth century.

Following the passage of the law in 1905 that segregated street cars in Tennessee, Richard H. Boyd and a group of Nashville businessmen decided to start an African American newspaper. This paper, the Nashville Globe, first appeared in newsstands in January 1906, and initial editions promoted the boycott of streetcars in reaction to the segregation law. The paper had close ties with the National Baptist Publishing Board, and all four original officers of the corporation Henry A. Boyd, Dock A. Hart, J.O. Battle, and Charles Burrill all worked for the National Baptist Publishing Board. The Globe favored businessmen, the Republican Party, preached an ethos of self-help and betterment, and supported the philosophies and teachings of Booker T. Washington. It remained in publication until 1960.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bartlett, Bobby, and the Free Hill Church of Christ

Hold to God's Unchanging Hand,a gospel song, was published in a Stamps-Baxter songbook. This performance of the Free Hill Church of Christ congregation led by Bobby Bartlett was recorded on March 13, 1983 by the Tennessee Folklore Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Addison Avenue looking north at Fisk University, Nashville, Tennessee, showing Jubilee Hall, Fisk Memorial chapel, and the Daniel Hand Model School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American universities and colleges; African American churches; African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image shows a stone-curbed street leading directly to Jubilee Hall, with three buildings, including a school-type building with small cupola bell tower, a cottage style house, and the Fisk Memorial chapel at right. Addison Avenue is now 17th Avenue South.

This photograph is one of at least sixteen images of African American businesses and homes in Nashville (several additional images of Fisk University and Roger Williams University students can be accessed here: http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/anedub/) that are part of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway. The purpose of the photographic exhibit in Paris was to show the history and present status of African Americans. 220 of the photographs are now in the collections of the Library of Congress, including 24 taken in Knoxville (4), Nashville (16), Chattanooga (3), and Memphis (1), Tennessee. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poll Tax Petition
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Voting Rights
Petitions; Poll tax; Suffrage
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A petition to repeal the poll tax.

Merl Eppse was a professor at Tennessee State University from 1928-1960. What is pictured here is a petition to repeal the poll tax. Poll taxes were enacted in Tennessee (and several other Southern states) as a way to disenfranchise those that they did not wish to participate in elections, such as African Americans. First enacted in 1870, it was not implemented by the legislature until 1889. In order to vote, one had to pay the poll tax; this act disenfranchised thousands of African Americans across the state. Beginning in the 1930s, groups such as the Tennessee Press Association and others, began to fight to have the poll tax law repealed. Petitions such as the ones seen here, were also circulated amongst the population and sent to Washington to protest the poll tax. The poll tax in Tennessee was repealed in 1953.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: TVA or "Lazy Man" Quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bond, Ruth Clement, Designer; Thomas, Rose Marie Phillips, Quiltmaker
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Silhouetted figure of a man, cut from black cloth, with his face turned in profile to his right, holds a silhouette of a guitar cut from red cloth in his left hand while his right hand stretches below towards a silhouette of the rays of a sun cut from orange cloth. He is surrounded by silhouettes of vegetation, cut from green and bluish green clothon three sides. A wide blue sleeve with a yellow star and band and what appears to be a white gloved hand touches his right shoulder. The central design block described here is surrounded by a plain wide light brown border, and the whole has been quilted in small squares.

The maker of this quilt was Rose Marie Phillips Thomas, whose husband, Wesley Marion Thomas, was in charge of education for African American workers employed by the Tennessee Valley Authority. This is one of at least four known examples of the same design made by the wives of African Americans employed by TVA on the construction of dams in northern Alabama. The design, which bears a striking resemblance to the silhouetted figurative style of Harlem Renaissance muralist Aaron Douglas, was suggested by Ruth Clement Bond, whose husband, Max J. Bond, was Personnel Officer at the Tennessee Valley Authority, 1934-38. Ruth Clement Bond, originally from Louisville, KY, was an educator and civic leader with a B.A. and M.A. in English from Northwestern University. She had been Head of the English department at Kentucky State College prior to coming to Wheeler Dam Village with her husband. After 1944, she taught at universities in Haiti, Liberia and Malawi and worked with women's and youth groups in Afghanistan, Tunisia and Sierra Leone. Her husband had earned a PhD in sociology and economics from USC in 1934. After his tenure at TVA, he served as Dean at Dillard University in New Orleans from 1938-1940 and Administrator at Tuskegee Institute from 1940-1944, when he joined the foreign service. He was President of the University of Liberia in the early 1950s. This information was excerpted from the essay, The TVA Quilts, in Soft Covers For Hard Times: Quiltmaking & the Great Depression, by Merikay Waldvogel (Nashville:Rutledge Hill Press,1990): 78-82.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Swimming pool at Lincoln Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African Americans; Swimming pools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The swimming pool at Lincoln Park, the African American park in Chattanooga.

In 1918, Chattanooga opened its first public park for African Americans, a ten acre park with a center fountain. In 1938, a swimming pool was opened at the park. The park grew to include a mini-zoo, a Ferris Wheel, a dance hall, and a baseball field. The park had the first lighted softball fields for African Americans in the South. The Chattanooga Choo-Choos, an African American baseball team, played many games at Lincoln Park. The pool was closed in 1996, and the city gave the park to Erlanger Hospital in 1979. During the height of its popularity, Lincoln Park drew African Americans from as far away as Birmingham and Atlanta.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young Men's Social Club
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Photographers
African American men -- Societies and clubs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the Young Men's Social Club. Note the tinting of the hats and ties of the gentlemen.

Knoxville's African American social life was lively and varied in the 1920s. According to historian Robert J. Booker, there were six dance halls in the black community by 1924. In the 1910s, several movie theaters opened in the Vine Street business district: the Gem and the Iola on Vine Street, and the Lincoln and Lyric theaters nearby. With the initiation of the East Tennessee Negro Fair at Chilhowee Park in 1925 came traveling acrobats, tap dancers, blues singers and minstrels, and boxing, and a dance band each evening. This photograph of dapper young men taken includes: seated, left to right, unidentified, Langley Tucker, Maynard James, Edgar Blair, Fred Miller; standing, left to right, Edward Ramsey, Robert Martin, Henry Jefferson, unidentified, unidentified, Hadyn Williams, Harvey Allen.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Roosevelt Election Headquarters
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Voting Rights
African Americans; Political campaigns
Automobiles; Buses; Men; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A group of five African American men and two women standing with a car and trailer parked in front of a two story brick building. The top story has been painted with the words "Roosevelt Headquarters."

In this photograph, a Democratic Party campaign trailer hitched to a late model automobile is parked in front of the Presnell building on Vine Street. Dr. James H. Presnell, who began practicing medicine in Knoxville in 1913, constructed this large brick building in 1922, at 503 Vine, the heart of Knoxville's African American business district. Dr. Presnell was an influential figure politically; when the Knoxville Flashlight Herald (a weekly African American paper) sponsored what historian Robert Booker calls a "bronze mayor" contest in 1937, Presnell was chosen to represent the community. Here, a marquee for the Atlanta Life Insurance Company hangs over the entry porch. There is a smaller marquee for Artcraft Studio below, and a sign for the Service Beauty School in the window at left. Two of the five men in the photograph wear military uniforms.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pikeville Chapel A.M.E. Zion Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Religious Institutions; Schools
African American churches; African American schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front-gable, frame building on a stone foundation, with attached steeple that forms a square tower entry vestibule on left side. The church is painted white, with a green raised seam metal roof, and located just across the Sequatchie River from Pikeville.

Thought to be the oldest rural African American church in Tennessee, this building also served as a school for African Americans until the construction of the Lincoln (Rosenwald) School in downtown Pikeville in 1925. Records of the county school superintendent for 1877 reveal that Fisk University students were serving as teachers, and that the school for African Americans was superior to the one for whites in Bledsoe County at the time. The church is located on a small rise beside the Sequatchie River, separated by a bridge from downtown Pikeville. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1999. According to research completed during the Rural African American Church survey conducted by the Center for Historic Preservation, it was known as the Mount Zion A.M.E. Church at one time. The steeple was added circa 1900. More information and additional images can be found in the Southern Places digital collection at MTSU Walker Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Aunt Jemima" Publicity Photograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kaufman-Fabry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African American women; African American women in advertising
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Official Photograph" of the Aunt Jemima pancake booth at the "Century of Progress" World's Fair, Chicago, 1933

The "Aunt Jemima" brand, which was based on a minstrel show character, originated in St. Louis in 1889. Quaker Oats, which had purchased the brand in 1926, hired several women to represent the popular brand, including Maude Woodfork McElroy, who was living in Chicago. However, this newspaper photograph does not appear to be of Maude Woodfork McElroy who may not have taken the position until sometime after the Chicago fair. The New York Age (29 March 1947) reported that McElroy had been hired to play the radio part of "Aunt Jemima" for a five-figure salary, that she had trained in the dramatic arts at Tennessee State University, and that she had originally come to Chicago to teach dramatics for the Works Progress Administration and that her husband, Charles McElroy, was a federal postal clerk in Chicago.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maryville Republican newspaper
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Media
African American newspapers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The front page of the Maryville Republican, an African American newspaper published in Maryville, Tennessee during Reconstruction.

The Maryville Republican was published by William Scott, Sr., a free black that moved to East Tennessee from North Carolina in 1847. Following the Civil War, Scott and his family moved to Nashville as Scott was a delegate to the Colored Men's Convention. During his time in Nashville, Scott and his son started the Colored Tennessean, the first African American newspaper in the state. Scott moved back to Maryville in 1866, and started publishing the Maryville Republican. The newspaper remained in publication until the 1880s.

Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Dwellings
Houses; Men; Women

Smith's grocery store in Knoxville. This is one of a group of 500 images that were gathered by W.E.B. DuBois and Thomas J. Calloway for display at the Paris Exposition of 1900. The identity of the photographer is not known, but it is possible it could have been DuBois himself, since he was well familiar with Tennessee, having graduated from Nashville's Fisk University in 1888. During his time at Fisk, he taught during summer breaks in Tennessee's rural areas, before continuing his graduate work at Harvard. In 1897, DuBois joined the faculty at Atlanta University and a good number of the photographs in this collection were also taken there. http://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/anedub/

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Symphony No. 9 in E minor B. 178 (Op. 95)- Largo "New World Symphony"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chicago Symphony Orchestra ; Sir Georg Solti, conductor
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
Symphonies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Short (approx 2 min) clip of largo movement from Dvorak's Symphony No. 9, "New World Symphony."

While a student at the National Conservatory of Music, H[arry].T[hacker]. Burleigh (1866-1949) became friends with composer Antonin Dvorak. Burleigh worked as a copyist for Dvorak and also introduced Dvorak to spirituals. African American spirituals as well as Native American music were important influences on Dvorak while he composed his New World Symphony in 1893.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jim Crow Train, performed by Josh White
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: White, Josh (1914-1969)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
Protest songs
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: United States -- New York (State) -- New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jim Crow Train" selection 23 from Josh White: Complete Recorded Works, volume 4, 4 June 1940-1941. Josh White is featured on vocals and guitar on six blues protest numbers recorded in New York City for Keynote Records.

Jim Crow Blues, with lyrics by Harlem Renaissance poet Waring Cuney, was one of six songs protesting the status of African Americans, which were recorded by Josh[ua Daniel] White (1914-1969) under the title "Southern Exposure: An Album of Jim Crow Blues." The songs were accompanied by notes written by Richard Wright. Other titles included in the same recording session were: Defense Factory Blues, Bad Housing Blues, Hard Times Blues, Uncle Sam Says, and Southern Exposure, which apparently addressed inequitable treatment of African Americans in the mobilization for World War II.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ticket to Roscoe Conklin Simmons Speech
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Civic Engagement
Speeches; Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ticket and stub for a speech by Roscoe Conklin (sic) Simmons on Sunday April 6 at the Ryman Auditorium. "Elks Ed Committee" appears at the bottom of the ticket.

Presumably, the speaker was Roscoe Conkling Simmons (1881-1951), a popular orator and Republican politician who had served as a foreign correspondent for the Chicago Defender during World War I. The addition of "Elks Ed Committee" at the bottom of the ticket suggests that the fraternal organization may have sponsored this public talk.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Uncle Sam's Helping Hand Quilt
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bond, Ruth Clement, designer; Cooper, Rose Lee, quiltmaker
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Work
Quilts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image was scanned from an 18 x 12 inch poster reproducing a quilt in the collection of the Tennessee Valley Authority. The text under the image is as follows: ''Uncle Sam's Helping Hand' This quilt was one of several made by African American women whose husbands worked on Wheeler Dam in Alabama in the 1930's. Many of these quilts conveyed appreciation for the improved living standard TVA brought to the region. 'Uncle Sam's Helping Hand' is on permanent display in TVA's Historical Collection in Knoxville, Tennessee."

This quilt was made by Rose Lee Cooper. It is one of several of the same design crafted by the wives of men employed at TVA's Wheeler, Pickwick, and other dam sites in northern Alabama. The design, which bears a striking resemblance to the silhouetted figurative style of Harlem Renaissance muralist Aaron Douglas, was suggested by Ruth Clement Bond, whose husband, Max J. Bond was Personnel Officer at the Tennessee Valley Authority, 1934-38. A period photograph of a similar quilt, which was used to illustrate an October 1935 article in The Crisis (NAACP journal) by John P. Davis about TVA's treatment of African American workers, captioned the image "Rugs made by wives of TVA workers in Muscle Shoals area. Motif from Aaron Douglas." Ruth Clement Bond, originally from Louisville, KY, was an educator and civic leader who had been Head of the English department at Kentucky State College prior to coming to Wheeler Dam Village with her husband. After 1944, she taught at universities in Haiti, Liberia and Malawi and worked with women's and youth groups in Afghanistan, Tunisia and Sierra Leone. Her husband had earned a PhD in sociology and economics from USC in 1934. Following his tenure at TVA, Max J. Bond served as Dean at Dillard University in New Orleans from 1938-1940 and Administrator at Tuskegee Institute from 1940-1944, when he joined the foreign service. He was President of the University of Liberia in the early 1950s. This information was excerpted from the essay, The TVA Quilts, in Soft Covers For Hard Times: Quiltmaking & the Great Depression, by Merikay Waldvogel (Nashville:Rutledge Hill Press,1990): 78-82. Bond, in an interview with Waldvogel, did not recall specifically modeling the work on that of Aaron Douglas, and also mentioned Henri Matisse as an influence.

Handy, and Lieutenant George Washington Lee, a World War I veteran who was also active in local politics. Handy's publishing company, Handy & Pace, was in business at this address until moving to New York City in 1918.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Cemeteries
African American cemeteries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Odd Fellows Cemetery was established in 1870. The Odd Fellows (the African American group is also known as the Grand United Order of Odd Fellows) were established in 1843 while the first Odd Fellows lodge for African Americans in Tennessee was established circa 1870. The Odd Fellows was a fraternal group with regalia and ranks for its members. Prominent Knoxvillians buried at this cemetery include Cal Johnson, Knoxville's first African American millionaire, and William Yardley, alderman and gubernatorial candidate.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Voting District 29-2, Memphis
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Reverend L.O.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Voting Rights
Suffrage; African Americans; African American men; African American women; African American children
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color film footage showing African American women standing in line, two African American men assisting a small boy walking on a porch, a sign reading 29-2 "Vote Here," African American men standing in line leading to tents with placards, and an African American man in a suit and zig-zag striped tie standing next to an automobile.

The Reverend Lonzie Odie Taylor (circa 1899-1977) became pastor of Olivet Baptist Church, 270 East Calhoun, Memphis, in 1931, serving the church until the 1950s. He was also a prolific photographer, whose black and white images of Memphis's African American community, both posed in a studio setting and in the busy business district of Beale Street and neighboring areas, captured a dynamic period of middle class prosperity and achievement from the 1920s to the 1960s. Taylor also made 16mm films, including this excerpt showing voters at a temporary neighborhood polling place. Blanche Taylor donated her husband's invaluable archive, which consists of thousands of negatives, five hundred still images, approximately 15 hours of color and black-and-white film, sound recordings, and manuscripts, to the Center for Southern Folklore.

Community leader and Austin High School Principal Charles W. Cansler (1871-1953), whose mother Laura had been one of the first to teach African American students in Knoxville, helped secure the donation of funds from the Carnegie Foundation. In May 1918, Cansler delivered the address at the formal dedication of Knoxville's first public library for African Americans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cal Johnson in his park
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African American businesspeople; African American philanthropists; African Americans; Parks
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Man in overcoat and cap standing at the top of steps with a two-story frame house in the background. He stands under an archway with lettering "Cal F. Johnson Park, Erected by Cal F. Johnson 1922."

According to historian Robert J. Booker, the city of Knoxville constructed this public park in honor of city leader Caldonia Fackler "Cal" Johnson (1844-1925). The five-acre park, located on Clinch Street, was one of two in Knoxville listed in a 1926 report describing recreational activities for African Americans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cal Johnson building
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
African American business enterprises; Storefronts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-story brick building on a street corner in commercial district. A neon marquee for the New York Cafe, and signs for a drug store soda fountain and a real estate office are also visible.

Caldonia Fackler "Cal" Johnson (1844-1925), the son of former slaves, was born in Knoxville. In the decades after the American Civil War, Johnson became a prosperous, law-abiding saloon owner, founded a horse-racing track, and owned several race horses. In 1896, he was invited by the East Tennessee Track Association to build a new track located in East Knoxville. He donated property for an African American YWCA in 1906 and constructed this commercial building at the corner of Vine and Central Avenues in 1915.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Benjamin "Pap" Singleton and S.A. McClure
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods
African Americans -- Migrations
Exodusters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photograph of Benjamin Singleton and S.A. McClure superimposed over an image, apparently taken in Nashville, Tennessee, of a steamboat with passengers.

Benjamin Singleton was born into slavery in 1809. He eventually escaped his owners and fled to Canada. Following the Civil War, Singleton returned to Nashville and organized a homestead assocation around 1869 with Columbus N. Johnson to promote the resettlement of African Americans to lands in the western United States. This movement was known as the "Exoduster" movement, and several thousand African Americans in Nashville and Middle Tennessee joined the movement, settling in townships in Kansas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John and Calvin and Barlow Roberts
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Free Hill Community Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community; Performing Identity
Musicians; Schools
African American musicians; African American men
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American three-piece string band, two older men with fiddles, a younger man in center with banjo, seated outside in straight back wooden chairs against an unpainted frame structure.

Free Hill, a neighborhood containing homes, a church and cemetery, and a former Rosenwald School, located on a hill near Celina, Tennessee, is a historically African American-owned community. There is an intact legacy of old-time string band musicians as well as sacred music associated with Free Hill. The Tennessee Folklore Society, in conjunction with the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project at the Department of Conservation, recorded an album entitled "Free Hill: A Sound Portrait of a Rural Afro-American Community (TFS 107) in 1983. It included not only musical selections but also historical remembrances and local lore. This photograph of members of the Barlow family is on display in the Free Hill Community Center, a well-preserved example of a two-room Rosenwald School.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trenton Rosenwald School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; African American students; African American teachers
Boys; Girls; Men; Students; Teachers; Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A photogaph of the teachers and students at Trenton Rosenwald School in Trenton, Tennessee, taken in 1939.

Trenton Rosenwald School was built in 1928-1929 as an eight-teacher school at the cost of $14,600. The Rosenwald Fund provided $2,100 for construction while the rest of the funds came from the African American community and public funds. This school design was one used for the construction of larger schools. In 1951, Carrie Booker Seats noted in her thesis about African American schools in Gibson County that the school had become overcrowded and was in the process of being renovated. At that time, the school had twelve grades and fifteen teachers. The building currently at this location was built in the 1950s-1960s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Community School Plan
Rosenwald School Plan
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Samuel L. Smith and Fletcher B. Dressler
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American schools; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings; School buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A floor plan for a five teacher school as part of the Community School Plans developed by Samuel L. Smith and Fletcher B. Dressler for the Rosenwald Fund.

In 1921, Samuel L. Smith and Fletcher B. Dressler published the first official Community School Plans bulletin for use by the Rosenwald Fund. These plans derived from earlier plans Smith had developed in the 1910s and that had already been used in some Rosenwald Schools. The plans show Smith and Dressler's belief in the importance of simplicity of design, the use of natural lighting, and the importance of sanitation. The plans oriented buildings as to maximize natural light, using banks of tall, narrow windows to provide adequate lighting for students. In addition to providing lighting, the windows also provided ventilation for the classroom and allowed for the circulation of air. The plans were designed for simplicity to make them affordable for local school boards to implement. The plans were offered without cost to both white and African American schools across the South, leading to the construction of many rural schools using these plans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baseball Team, Tennessee State Technical & Agricultural School for Colored Boys, Pikeville
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community; Performing Identity
Athletes; Schools
African American baseball players; African American schools; African American students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sixteen young men, standing in two rows outside of a plaster-covered building. Fifteen are wearing baseball caps and uniforms with the letters S.T.A.S. across the front; one wears a plain uniform. There is a man with a plain uniform and no cap at front center, holding a bat atop a pile of baseball gloves. An older man wearing a plain uniform and a hat with brim stands between the rows at far left.

The State of Tennessee created several "state training schools" or reform schools for teenaged offenders. Originally called the school for "negro boys," this school on the Cumberland Plateau, just up the mountain from Pikeville, was later renamed the Tennessee State Technical & Agricultural School for Colored Boys. This image of a baseball team, posed against the wall of a modern-looking building, probably dates from after 1945, as facilities at the school were remodeled and upgraded about that time. The posed photograph seems designed to give the impression that recreational activities were a regular part of life for the young inmates.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pikeville School for Colored Boys
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American boys; African American schools; African American students
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thirty-five or more young African Americans, many wearing overalls, standing or seated at school desks and pew-like benches in a room with brick walls and a wood floor.

In the early decades of the twentieth century, the State of Tennessee created several "state training schools" or reform schools for teenaged offenders. The school for "negro boys" was located near Pikeville on the Cumberland Plateau. Conditions there came to public attention after a violent series of events in 1944 that included the apparent murder of the wife and daughter of superintendent H.E. Scott and the "lynching" of the teenager suspected of killing the two. After revelations that the facilities were inadequate, overcrowded, and unsanitary, modern fire-proof buildings were constructed in 1945.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peiser the tailor, Klinke the ice cream maker, the delivery man, the Italian restaurant owner, O'Nearn the Irish policeman
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Policemen; Restaurateurs; Tailors
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five white men seated on a long bench in front of a brick wall. The man on far left is the only one not wearing a hat, and all are in shirtsleeves except for the man at far right who wears a policeman's uniformand holds a stick across his lap. Painted letters from advertisements on the wall are visible behind the men.

This image represents business owners in "the Pinch," a business district of mixed ethnicity in downtown Memphis. The area was first settled in tthe 1830s, primarily by Irish immigrants. By the turn of the twentieth century, it included Jewish, Italian, and other ethnic groups, who built businesses and raised their families in nearby neighborhoods.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: People in a bar near Beale Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Taylor, Reverend L.O.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
African Americans; African American business enterprises
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of a restaurant in six men in shirtsleeves and straw hats are seated at square tables with quart bottles of beer and glasses in front of them. One woman is seated at a table in the back, white two white uniformed waitresses prepare food and drinks behind a counter on left. A young boy and a man without a hat stand at the counter, which has two soda bottles on it. A hand-lettered menu is visible on the back wall, advertising hot dogs for 10 cents, hamburgers for 15 cents, cheeseburgers for 25 cents and a list of other items including cold drinks and cakes and pies.

The Reverend Lonzie Odie Taylor (circa 1899-1977) was pastor of Olivet Baptist Church in Memphis in the 1930s, 1940s, and early 1950s. He was also a skilled photographer and many of his images captured people and places in the Beale Street business district. In this photograph, everyone in the restaurant is looking directly at the photographer, acknowledging his right to record the moment.

This composite portrait represents Tennessee's 45th General Assembly, which served from 1887-1888. The three African American state representatives can be found grouped together at the bottom right: Styles Linton Hutchins (1852-1950), Hamilton County; Monroe W. Gooden (1852-1915), Fayette County; Samuel Allen McElwee (1859-1914), Haywood County. Gooden was the first African American legislator to be elected from the Democratic Party in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: New York Age Print
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Transportation
Lynching
African American women
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All its Phases. Miss Ida B. Wells. New York Age Print, 1892. A cream colored booklet with image of the author.

Ida B. Wells (1862-1931) was born in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the daughter of former slaves. While teaching in a public school, just outside of the city of Memphis, she mounted an unsuccessful challenge to the segregation of public railroad cars in Memphis. Although she was at first awarded damages in her lawsuit challenging the Chesapeake, Ohio and Southwestern Railroad Company, the victory was overturned by the Tennessee Supreme Court in 1887. Wells became an outspoken advocate for African American rights and began publishing articles in African American newspapers, first in Memphis and later nationall. In 1892, Wells wrote to the New York Age, to protest the closing of her Memphis newspaper, The Free Speech. This booklet, which was reprinted in 1893 and 1894, is an expanded version of her June 25, 1892 editorial.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee General Assembly, composite photograph of the 44th legislature
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Civic Engagement
African American legislators; Legislators
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders photographs arranged to form a group portrait against a rectangular background. Images are numbered and names keyed to a list below the group portrait.

This composite portrait represents Tennessee's 44th General Assembly, which served from 1885-1886. The four African American state representatives can be found grouped together at the bottom right of the grouping. Not shown here are Leonidas Howard (1849-1912) who served in the 43rd General Assembly, representing Shelby County; John William Boyd (ca. 1850-1932), who represented Tipton County in both the 42nd and 43rd legislatures; and David Foote Rivers (1859-1941), who served in the 43rd legislature from Fayette County. The African American members of the 44th General Assembly can be identified by numbers written below their portraits in ink: 33, Greene E. Evans (1848-1914), Shelby County; 35, William Alexander Fields (ca. 1852-1898), Shelby County; 48, William Calvin Hodge (ca.1846-ca.1900), Hamilton County; 62, Samuel Allen McElwee (1859-1914), Haywood County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pastoral: Fulani & Infant
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Baldridge, Cyrus
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Artists
Blacks in art; Infants in art; Women in art
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Woman in colorful woven wrap garment, with ornamental hair braids, metal hoop earrings, and jewelry including cowrie shell necklace, holding an infant, signed Baldridge at lower right.

Artist and illustrator Cyrus Leroy Baldridge (1889-1977) attended the Chicago School of Illustration as a boy. He worked as an illustrator after graduation from the University of Chicago and served as a war correspondent during World War I. While in the American infantry, he contributed to the Stars and Stripes, Leslie's Weekly and Scribners. His first book "I Was There with the Yanks in France" was a collection of his wartime sketches. After his marriage to Caroline Singer, the two traveled in Africa, mostly along the west coast, during the mid to late 1920s, staying in native villages in order to glean an understanding of the homelands and customs of the ancestors of contemporary African Americans. W.W. Norton published their book, entitled "White Africans and Black," written by Singer and illustrated by Baldridge, in 1929. During his career, Baldridge illustrated books for African American authors and worked for Opportunity, the magazine of the Urban League. Chicago businessman Samuel Insull purchased the collection of sketches from Baldridge's African sojourn and donated them to Fisk University in 1931.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lowenstein House
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Dwellings; Historic buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-and-one half story brick house with stone-arched center entry and an open arched wrap-around front porch on right. The house features a tower cupola, echoed by a decorative dormer window below on the left side, a pyramid roofline with cross gable dormers, several chimneys, a stained glass fan light window and a pierced stone rose window.
Elias Lowenstein's handsome 1891 home is representative of the wide array of fine Victorian houses built by wealthy Memphians in the prosperous decades before and after the American Civil War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Facts Every Negro Should Know about Roosevelt
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Voting Rights
Roosevelt, Franklin D. (Franklin Delano), 1882-1945; Voting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four-sheet broadside announcing a Victory Meeting at Church Park Auditorium on Monday Night, Nov. 4, 1940, 8 pm, issued by the Colored Democratic Club, Memphis, Tennessee, Dr. J.E. Walker, Chairman; T.J. Johnson, Director of Publicity

This informational pamphlet, Facts Every Negro Should Know about Roosevelt and the Democratic Administration, has a head shot of Franklin D. Roosevelt on the cover page, with the slogan "Keep Him in Office and Keep the Negro Moving Forward" just below. The broadside announcing the "victory meeting" has the names of those on the ticket with Roosevelt on the voting date of Tuesday November 5th, including Tennessee candidates K.D. McKellar (U.S. Senate); Governor Prentice Cooper, and Congressman Clifford Davis, as well as Utilities Commissioner Porter Dunlap. Also announced is the promotion of Benjamin Davis to Brigadier General in the U.S. Army, which was touted as an accomplishment of the adminstration. The other pages contain facts and figures about government agency accomplishments that had particularly benefited African Americans, as well as African American appointed officials in various departments.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee General Assembly, composite photograph of the 42nd legislature
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schleier
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Embracing Citizenship
Civic Engagement
African American legislators; Legislators
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders photographs arranged to form a group portrait in the shape of a flat oval placed against a rectangular background. Images are numbered and names keyed to a list below the group portrait.

This composite portrait represents Tennessee's 42nd General Assembly, which served from 1881-1882. Four of Tennessee's earliest African American state representatives can be found grouped together at far left in this image. Not pictured here is Sampson Wesley Keeble (1833-1857), the first African American elected to the Tennessee General Assembly. Keeble served one term only, in the 38th legislature, from 1873-1874. There were no African American legislators elected to three subsequent General Assemblies, the 39th, 40th, and 41st. The African American members of the 42nd General Assembly can be located by number written on the image in white lettering: 59, Thomas A. Sykes (1838-ca.1895), Davidson County; 61, Thomas Frank Cassels (ca. 1845-1903), Shelby County; 62, Isham Franklin Norris (1851-1928), Shelby County; and 63, John William Boyd (ca. 1850-1932), Tipton County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Evidences of the Progress of a Race
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Green, Henry Morgan
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Wilson, Bartow G., Charles W. Cansler, and Henry Morgan Green. The Knoxville Negro: Emphasizing the Great Era of Progress Prevalent in Negro Knoxville Today. Knoxville [Tenn.]: Trent Printing Co., 1929.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
National Leaders
African Americans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Essay by Dr. Henry Morgan Green in The Knoxville Negro, published by Trent Printing Co. 2104 Magnolia Ave. Knoxville, Tenn. U.S.A., June 1929

In the opening essay for this promotional booklet, Dr. Henry Morgan Green, a pioneering Knoxville physician and esteemed community leader, assessed the social and material growth of Knoxville's African American population. Green was well-qualified to analyze the city's progress, having graduated from Knoxville College, helped found a short-lived medical college there, and been successful in his own medical practice. He also chaired the Negro Department at the Appalachian Exposition of 1910, at which a handsome separate building, designed and built by African Americans, was erected to house exhibits related to African American accomplishments. In this essay, Green lays out what he sees as four important measures of progress that would place Knoxville in the forefront of American cities of the period: moral worth (the number of churches and congregations); intellectual achievement (notable educational institutions); material growth (home and business ownership); and industrial application. Of the latter, he wrote "Knoxville through its multitudinous industrial activities, furnishes an abundance of opportunities for gainful occupation . . . because of the cordial race relations existing, he [the Knoxville Negro] has access to all kinds of classes of labor..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James & Allen Drug Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
African American business enterprises
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior of a drug store with soda fountain at front right and glass cased pharmacy counter at left. Four persons are inside the store. A boy sits on a chair at back left and a man in a three-piece suit stands in front of him next to the glass cases. Seated on one of several wooden stools with cane seats at the soda fountain counter is a man in bowler hat, while a uniformed attendant leans on one elbow behind the counter. Electric light fixtures hang from the ceiling and the back wall has a wallpaper patterned border at top.

The East Side Pharmacy, James & Allen, proprietors was on East 9th Street in the James Building. The three-story brick building was erected by Dr. O.W. James. Above the street-level store front were office and lodge rooms, according to J. Bliss White's 1904 Biography and Achievements of the Colored Citizens of Chattanooga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
Parks; Historic buildings; African American philanthropists
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A two story structure stands at the center of what appears to be a rectangular park, with pathways leading to the building from several directions. Medium sized trees are spaced evenly and two streetlamps are visible in this photo, which is captioned "View of the Church Park from entrance gate."

Robert R. Church purchased six acres of land on Beale Street at Fourth Avenue on which to build a park in 1899. On it he erected an a modern auditorium, which could accomodate over two thousand persons, complete with a banquet hall and soda fountain. Church's Park was the center of urban African American entertainment and political activity in Memphis. Although the auditorium is no longer extant, the park was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1993.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hubbard Hospital and Meharry Medical College
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Achieving Recognition
Medical profession
African Americans -- Hospitals; Meharry Medical College
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Meharry Medical College began in 1876 as the medical school of Central Tennessee College, established by the Freedmen's Aid Society. The founder and first president was George W. Hubbard, a former Union soldier. In 1915, Meharry Medical College was granted a charter separate from Central Tennessee College. The college moved to north Nashville, one block from Fisk University, in the late 1920s, and its new buildings adopted the collegiate gothic style of architecture found on the neighboring Fisk campus. Meharry Medical College grew to include a School of Dentistry, a School of Medicine, and a School of Nursing, as well as other departments. Meharry Medical College continues to educate health care professionals.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lansky Brothers Men's Shop on Famous Beale Street
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Business Districts
Beale Street (Memphis, Tenn.); Business enterprises; Men's clothing industry; Storefronts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the exterior of two story brick commercial building with plate glass storefont below, neon sign for "Lansky Bros Men's Shop on famous Beale Street" out front, and the number 126 and the words "shoes, uniforms, formal wear for rent, jewelry, luggage, hats" painted in block letters on second level. Next door is a sign for Miss River Cafe.

Lansky's was a menswear store located at 126 Beale Street, near the corner of south Second Street, in Memphis, from 1946 until the 1980s, when it moved into new spaces in the lobby of the Peabody Hotel at 149 Union. Samuel Lansky put up the money to purchase a store on Beale Street for his sons just after World War II. Bernard (1927-2012) built the business from a dry goods store, to an army surplus store, to a fashion center. Through his personal relationship with Elvis Presley, he turned it into an internationally-acclaimed celebrity outfitter and tourist mecca. As Lansky related it in a 2005 interview, Elvis rented a tuxedo when he was in high school and bought his first suit there, continuing to buy tailored jackets, pants, and coats from Bernard Lansky throughout his career. Lansky's descendants still own and operate the Lansky stores at the Peabody Hotel.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oh Daddy Blues
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity
Musicians
African American women singers; Blues (Music)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scan of sheet music cover for Oh Daddy Blues by Bessie Smith.

The Empress of the Blues, Bessie Smith (1894-1937), was one of the greatest singers of the 1920s and 1930s. Smith started her singing career as a street performer and was later a protg of Ma Rainey. In 1915, Smith went out on her own to become a popular vaudeville performer. In 1923 she made her debut as a recording artist for the Columbia label and during her recording career she performed with blues and jazz greats such as Louis Armstrong, Coleman Hawkins and James P. Johnson. Smith recorded Oh Daddy Blues in 1923.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bailey, DeFord
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Performing Identity

African American musicians
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This audio clip (1 min 3 sec) features a low and mournful harmonica.

According to the biography of the Tennessee Grand Ole Opry star harmonica player DeFord Bailey (1899-1982), which was written by David C. Morton with Charles K. Wolfe, Nashville's Zema W. Hill, a funeral home owner and minister, who Bailey considered "a powerful preacher," was the inspiration for this composition. ["DeFord Bailey: A Black Star in Early Country Music" (Knoxville: University of Tennessee, 1991), p. 67] The song was recorded on the Brunswick label, on April 19, 1927, in New York City.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Promise Land School
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Towns, Neighborhoods; Schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: White frame, front gable one-story building on stone foundation, with side gable ell. Handlettered sign over door.

Promise Land community was first settled by freedmen during Reconstruction.The African American Bowen, Redden, and Vanleer families purchased one thousand acres in what would become Promise Land circa 1870. In 1881, the Nesbitt brothers purchased land for a school and a church, forming the nucleus of the community. By 1900, there were three churches in the community as well as several stores. The building pictured here was partially constructed in 1899, replacing an earlier school which had been destroyed by fire. Promise Land may have been Dickson County's largest African American community during the first half of the twentieth century. The school, closed in 1957, is now used as a community center.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Title on mat: LeMoyne Normal Institute, 1908-1909, Professor L.T. Larsen, Prin., Memphis, Tennessee. A group of white and African American men and women posed on steps of a frame building with brick foundation.

In 1870, Dr. Francis J. LeMoyne, a Pennsylvania doctor and abolitionist, donated $20,000 to the American Missionary Association to build an elementary and secondary school for prospective teachers. The designation "Normal School" was a common designation signaling that an institution was devoted to teacher training.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ida Wells Case
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Transportation
Segregation in transportation -- United States -- Cases; Wells-Barnett, Ida B., -- 1862-1931; African American women civil rights workers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of a published legal brief filed by Greer & Adams and T.F. Cassels, and sections 19-23 of transcribed testimony regarding a case before the Tennessee Supreme Court in April 1885.

On September 15th 1883, twenty-year old, Fisk University-educated, school teacher Ida B. Wells purchased a ticket for a trip by train from Memphis to Woodstock (ten miles north of Memphis), where she was teaching at a public school. She chose a seat in the rear car with white ladies and gentlemen but was forcibly removed and told to move to the forward car, where smoking and drinking were allowed and where black and white passengers rode together. She refused and sought damages in a challenge to Tennessee's 1882 statute, which ordered common carriers to provide "accomodations equal in all respects in comfort and convenience to the first-class cars on the train..." for non-white passengers. The case, in which she was represented by prominent Memphis attorney, Thomas Frank Cassels, a free black who had served in the 42nd Tennessee General Assembly (1881-1883), was appealed to the Tennessee Supreme Court in April 1885. The Court found for the Railroad Company, reversing the earlier decision by the Circuit Court of Shelby County.
